page.title: 11THE CAUSES OF MOORLAND FIRES
page.content: The moors are a very popular area for visitors.They tend to visit the area far more in summer than in winter,but this coincides with the time of greatest danger from fires.The wind and warmer weather can combine to create a highly dangerous mix of dry heather and peat.The heather acts as kindling for the peat.The peat can attain a depth of over twenty five feet on the flat moorland plateau. Fires on the moors are mainly caused through negligence of visitors.The dropping of matches and cigarettes,the leaving of broken glass can cause small grass fires.These soon spread and cause the much more dangerous peat fire which not only burns on the surface but hidden at depth.These can remain hidden and days later erupt in flames.
